awd_titl_txt: RUI: Modulation of cation exchange using oxidation/reduction to design plasmonic nanoheterostructures
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstracts for RUI: Modulation of cation exchange using oxidation/reduction to design plasmonic nanoheterostructures DMR-2003337 
 
PART 1:   NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY
One route to create next-generation nanomaterials is by taking single nanoparticles and transforming them into more complex structures. The process starts with one form of nanoparticle and trades out one type of atom for another. This leaves the nanoparticle with the same size and shape it started with, but with additional chemical components. This useful, but not yet fully understood, process is called cation exchange. This project, supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program in the Division of Materials Research, uncovers how one can change the outcome of cation exchange by altering the features of the starting nanoparticle. It is expected that this will affect how much the particle changes in chemistry and where the new components go. It will also change the way the particles absorb light. The insights into how cation exchange works gained through these experiments will allow control over chemistry and structure on the nanoscale. This will eventually make it possible to design and create complex nanodevices that have a broad range of applications that are important to society, particularly in sensing and solar energy conversion. In addition to the benefits that come from directly from the science, training in materials chemistry will be strengthened through undergraduate research and an innovative partnership between laboratories at a primarily undergraduate institution and at an R1 university. Research infrastructure in the Central Pennsylvania region will be supported and barriers to broad participation in chemistry and materials will be reduced.  

PART 2:   TECHNICAL SUMMARY
Starting with copper sulfide nanoparticles, designed nanoheterostructures are created through selective introduction of new components through cation exchange. Preliminary data show that iodine oxidation of roxbyite nanoparticles alters the propensity for cation exchange with cadmium and zinc ions as it simultaneously alters the localized surface plasmon resonance of copper sulfide particles. It is proposed that oxidation/reduction processes can be employed as tools to modulate chemical and spatial selectivity of partial cation exchange. This project, supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program within the Division of Materials Research, seeks to reveal structure-property relationships affected by the alteration of copper sulfide nanoparticles through redox processes and to utilize these relationships to design novel plasmonic nanoheterostructures. The project examines various means of oxidation and reduction and elucidates the effects on structure, Cu-ion vacancy concentration, plasmonic behavior, and propensity for cation exchange in copper sulfide nanoparticles. The fundamental insights uncovered by the proposed work will advance our ability to control chemistry and structure on the nanoscale. The particles investigated have the potential to act as catalysts, solar energy absorbers in PV or solar water evaporation, NIR absorbers in photothermal cancer treatment, or sensors. Training in materials chemistry will be strengthened through undergraduate research with close student-faculty interaction and an innovative partnership between laboratories at a primarily undergraduate institution and at an R1 university. Research infrastructure in the Central Pennsylvania region will be supported and barriers to broad participation in chemistry and materials research will be reduced.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit:

The overarching goal of this project was to create new types of nanoparticles that contain multiple chemical components in specific locations within the particle through post-synthetic transformation. In other words, we seek to make complicated particles that would be useful for solar energy conversion, photocatalysis, thermoelectrics, and ion batteries by starting with easy-to-make simple particles and then treating them in ways to change their chemistry. In addition to studying cation exchange and redox-doping, we discovered that anion exchange can be performed on copper sulfide nanoparticles. We developed a tellurium exchange procedure that results in several different patterns of copper sulfide and copper telluride within the same particle. Notably, this is one of few systems where anion exchange does not result in voids in the center of the particle. We investigated the light absorption behavior of these different copper sulfide/copper telluride structures. We found that one of the light absorption mechanisms, called localized surface plasmon resonance, is quenched with low-levels of tellurium exchange. This opens opportunities for tuning the light absorption behavior for these materials. Furthermore, we discovered a system where selenium can be incorporated into copper sulfide nanoparticles, creating various shapes and placements of copper selenide. Two different transformation mechanisms were uncovered. Low temperatures caused simultaneous dissolution of copper sulfide with directed growth of copper selenide. Higher temperatures caused formation of molecules that resulted in selenium anion exchange. 

Broader impacts:

This work was carried out by undergraduate students at a primarily undergraduate institution (PUI). Undergraduate research is one of the most powerful means of training the generation of scientists, improving student's resilience, sense of belonging, problem-solving skills, leadership, and communication skills. 33 undergraduate students participated over 4 years, including 19 women and 9 underrepresented minority students.. Students worked in peer-mentored teams to improve skill transfer and student's ownership of their projects. 

We worked to improve nanomaterials infrastructure by working with Pennsylvania State University to implement remote use of their transmission electron microscopes. This new system is sufficiently straightforward that undergraduate students can quickly learn to use advanced instrumentation.
